column2: Part IV
column3: Part four

column2: 46 Jakes and the Lady
column3: forty six Jakes and the Lady

column2: I was sold to a corn dealer and baker, whom Jerry knew, and with him he thought I should have good food and fair work.
column3: I was sold to a corn dealer and baker, whom Jerry knew, and with him he thought I should have good food and fair work.

column2: In the first he was quite right, and if my master had always been on the premises I do not think I should have been overloaded, but there was a foreman who was always hurrying and driving every one, and frequently when I had quite a full load he would order something else to be taken on.
column3: In the first he was quite right, and if my master had always been on the premises I do not think I should have been overloaded, but there was a foreman who was always hurrying and driving every one, and frequently when I had quite a full load he would order something else to be taken on.

column2: My carter, whose name was Jakes, often said it was more than I ought to take, but the other always overruled him.
column3: My carter, whose name was Jakes, often said it was more than I ought to take, but the other always overruled him.

column2: 'Twas no use going twice when once would do, and he chose to get business forward.
column3: 'twas no use going twice when once would do, and he chose to get business forward.

column2: Jakes, like the other carters, always had the check-rein up, which prevented me from drawing easily, and by the time I had been there three or four months I found the work telling very much on my strength.
column3: Jakes, like the other carters, always had the check rein up, which prevented me from drawing easily, and by the time I had been there three or four months I found the work telling very much on my strength.

column2: One day I was loaded more than usual, and part of the road was a steep uphill.
column3: One day I was loaded more than usual, and part of the road was a steep uphill.

column2: I used all my strength, but I could not get on, and was obliged continually to stop.
column3: I used all my strength, but I could not get on, and was obliged continually to stop.

column2: This did not please my driver, and he laid his whip on badly.
column3: This did not please my driver, and he laid his whip on badly.

column2: Get on, you lazy fellow, he said, "or I'll make you."
column3: Get on, you lazy fellow, he said, "or I'll make you."

column2: Again I started the heavy load, and struggled on a few yards; again the whip came down, and again I struggled forward.
column3: Again I started the heavy load, and struggled on a few yards; again the whip came down, and again I struggled forward.

column2: The pain of that great cart whip was sharp, but my mind was hurt quite as much as my poor sides.
column3: The pain of that great cart whip was sharp, but my mind was hurt quite as much as my poor sides.

column2: To be punished and abused when I was doing my very best was so hard it took the heart out of me.
column3: To be punished and abused when I was doing my very best was so hard it took the heart out of me.

column2: A third time he was flogging me cruelly, when a lady stepped quickly up to him, and said in a sweet, earnest voice:
column3: A third time he was flogging me cruelly, when a lady stepped quickly up to him, and said in a sweet, earnest voice:

column2: Oh! pray do not whip your good horse any more; I am sure he is doing all he can, and the road is very steep; I am sure he is doing his best.
column3: Oh! pray do not whip your good horse any more; I am sure he is doing all he can, and the road is very steep; I am sure he is doing his best.

column2: If doing his best won't get this load up he must do something more than his best; that's all I know, ma'am, said Jakes.
column3: If doing his best won't get this load up he must do something more than his best; that's all I know, ma'am, said Jakes.

column2: But is it not a heavy load? she said.
column3: But is it not a heavy load? she said.

column2: Yes, yes, too heavy, he said; "but that's not my fault; the foreman came just as we were starting, and would have three hundredweight more put on to save him trouble, and I must get on with it as well as I can."
column3: Yes, yes, too heavy, he said; "but that's not my fault; the foreman came just as we were starting, and would have three hundredweight more put on to save him trouble, and I must get on with it as well as I can."

column2: He was raising the whip again, when the lady said:
column3: He was raising the whip again, when the lady said:

column2: Pray, stop; I think I can help you if you will let me.
column3: Pray, stop; I think I can help you if you will let me.

column2: The man laughed.
column3: The man laughed.

column2: You see, she said, "you do not give him a fair chance; he cannot use all his power with his head held back as it is with that check-rein; if you would take it off I am sure he would do better--do try it," she said persuasively, "I should be very glad if you would."
column3: You see, she said, "you do not give him a fair chance; he cannot use all his power with his head held back as it is with that check rein; if you would take it off I am sure he would do better-do try it," she said persuasively, "I should be very glad if you would."

column2: Well, well, said Jakes, with a short laugh, "anything to please a lady, of course.
column3: Well, well, said Jakes, with a short laugh, "anything to please a lady, of course.

column2: How far would you wish it down, ma'am?"
column3: How far would you wish it down, ma'am?"

column2: Quite down, give him his head altogether.
column3: Quite down, give him his head altogether.

column2: The rein was taken off, and in a moment I put my head down to my very knees.
column3: The rein was taken off, and in a moment I put my head down to my very knees.

column2: What a comfort it was!
column3: What a comfort it was!

column2: Then I tossed it up and down several times to get the aching stiffness out of my neck.
column3: Then I tossed it up and down several times to get the aching stiffness out of my neck.

column2: Poor fellow! that is what you wanted, said she, patting and stroking me with her gentle hand; "and now if you will speak kindly to him and lead him on I believe he will be able to do better."
column3: Poor fellow! that is what you wanted, said she, patting and stroking me with her gentle hand; "and now if you will speak kindly to him and lead him on I believe he will be able to do better."

column2: Jakes took the rein.
column3: Jakes took the rein.

column2: Come on, Blackie. I put down my head, and threw my whole weight against the collar; I spared no strength; the load moved on, and I pulled it steadily up the hill, and then stopped to take breath.
column3: Come on, Blackie. I put down my head, and threw my whole weight against the collar; I spared no strength; the load moved on, and I pulled it steadily up the hill, and then stopped to take breath.

column2: The lady had walked along the footpath, and now came across into the road.
column3: The lady had walked along the footpath, and now came across into the road.

column2: She stroked and patted my neck, as I had not been patted for many a long day.
column3: She stroked and patted my neck, as I had not been patted for many a long day.

column2: You see he was quite willing when you gave him the chance; I am sure he is a fine-tempered creature, and I dare say has known better days.	You see he was quite willing when you gave him the chance; I am sure he is a fine tempered creature, and I dare say has known better days.
column3: false

column2: You won't put that rein on again, will you?" for he was just going to hitch it up on the old plan.
column3: You won't put that rein on again, will you?" for he was just going to hitch it up on the old plan.

column2: Well, ma'am, I can't deny that having his head has helped him up the hill, and I'll remember it another time, and thank you, ma'am; but if he went without a check-rein I should be the laughing-stock of all the carters; it is the fashion, you see.
column3: Well, ma'am, I can't deny that having his head has helped him up the hill, and I'll remember it another time, and thank you, ma'am; but if he went without a check rein I should be the laughing stock of all the carters; it is the fashion, you see.

column2: Is it not better, she said, "to lead a good fashion than to follow a bad one?
column3: Is it not better, she said, "to lead a good fashion than to follow a bad one?

column2: A great many gentlemen do not use check-reins now; our carriage horses have not worn them for fifteen years, and work with much less fatigue than those who have them; besides," she added in a very serious voice, "we have no right to distress any of God's creatures without a very good reason; we call them dumb animals, and so they are, for they cannot tell us how they feel, but they do not suffer less because they have no words.
column3: A great many gentlemen do not use check reins now; our carriage horses have not worn them for fifteen years, and work with much less fatigue than those who have them; besides," she added in a very serious voice, "we have no right to distress any of God's creatures without a very good reason; we call them dumb animals, and so they are, for they cannot tell us how they feel, but they do not suffer less because they have no words.

column2: But I must not detain you now; I thank you for trying my plan with your good horse, and I am sure you will find it far better than the whip.
column3: But I must not detain you now; I thank you for trying my plan with your good horse, and I am sure you will find it far better than the whip.

column2: Good-day," and with another soft pat on my neck she stepped lightly across the path, and I saw her no more.
column3: Good day," and with another soft pat on my neck she stepped lightly across the path, and I saw her no more.

column2: That was a real lady, I'll be bound for it, said Jakes to himself; "she spoke just as polite as if I was a gentleman, and I'll try her plan, uphill, at any rate;" and I must do him the justice to say that he let my rein out several holes, and going uphill after that, he always gave me my head; but the heavy loads went on.
column3: That was a real lady, I'll be bound for it, said Jakes to himself; "she spoke just as polite as if I was a gentleman, and I'll try her plan, uphill, at any rate;" and I must do him the justice to say that he let my rein out several holes, and going uphill after that, he always gave me my head; but the heavy loads went on.

column2: Good feed and fair rest will keep up one's strength under full work, but no horse can stand against overloading; and I was getting so thoroughly pulled down from this cause that a younger horse was bought in my place.
column3: Good feed and fair rest will keep up one's strength under full work, but no horse can stand against overloading; and I was getting so thoroughly pulled down from this cause that a younger horse was bought in my place.

column2: I may as well mention here what I suffered at this time from another cause.
column3: I may as well mention here what I suffered at this time from another cause.

column2: I had heard horses speak of it, but had never myself had experience of the evil; this was a badly-lighted stable; there was only one very small window at the end, and the consequence was that the stalls were almost dark.
column3: I had heard horses speak of it, but had never myself had experience of the evil; this was a badly lighted stable; there was only one very small window at the end, and the consequence was that the stalls were almost dark.

column2: Besides the depressing effect this had on my spirits, it very much weakened my sight, and when I was suddenly brought out of the darkness into the glare of daylight it was very painful to my eyes.
column3: Besides the depressing effect this had on my spirits, it very much weakened my sight, and when I was suddenly brought out of the darkness into the glare of daylight it was very painful to my eyes.

column2: Several times I stumbled over the threshold, and could scarcely see where I was going.
column3: Several times I stumbled over the threshold, and could scarcely see where I was going.

column2: I believe, had I stayed there very long, I should have become purblind, and that would have been a great misfortune, for I have heard men say that a stone-blind horse was safer to drive than one which had imperfect sight, as it generally makes them very timid.
column3: I believe, had I stayed there very long, I should have become purblind, and that would have been a great misfortune, for I have heard men say that a stone blind horse was safer to drive than one which had imperfect sight, as it generally makes them very timid.

column2: However, I escaped without any permanent injury to my sight, and was sold to a large cab owner.
column3: However, I escaped without any permanent injury to my sight, and was sold to a large cab owner.

column2: 47 Hard Times
column3: forty seven Hard Times

column2: My new master I shall never forget; he had black eyes and a hooked nose, his mouth was as full of teeth as a bull-dog's, and his voice was as harsh as the grinding of cart wheels over graveled stones.
column3: My new master I shall never forget; he had black eyes and a hooked nose, his mouth was as full of teeth as a bull dog's, and his voice was as harsh as the grinding of cart wheels over graveled stones.

column2: His name was Nicholas Skinner, and I believe he was the man that poor Seedy Sam drove for.
column3: His name was Nicholas Skinner, and I believe he was the man that poor Seedy Sam drove for.
